title-group.article-title: Psychoanalytic Politics: Chaucer and Two Peasants

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 2001 The Johns Hopkins University Press

Fradenburg's: "it takes as an analogy between entities presumed to be discrete and to have autonomous origins and evolutionary paths what is both more and other than an analogy-what in fact involves the interaction of social individuals and the mutual articulation of psychoanalytic and social categories" (65)
Jameson, Political Unconscious, 65 ("the sexual"; "the occasion"), 64 ("remains"; "banal").

Donald Howard, The Idea of the Canterbury Tales [Berkeley: Univ. of California Press, 1976], 231

H. M. Leicester, whose focus in The Disenchanted Self Representing the Subject in the Canterbury Tales (Berkeley: Univ. of California Press, 1990) is on how "the "the world of a given tale" characterizes its speaker and "how that speaker's telling creates him or her in the course of the narration" (13)

Leicester poses some of the problems of such criticism: "[i]t is hard (impossible in principle, I suspect) to know whether the origin of ... unconscious structures is in the pilgrim narrator (Chaucer consciously represents what the pilgrim is unconscious of), in Chaucer himself, or in me (why not if there is anything to transference?). These are not mutually exclusive possibilities" (17-18)
Samuel Weber, Return to Freud: Jacques Lacan's Dislocation of Psychoanalysis, trans. Michael Levine [Cambridge: Cambridge Univ. Press, 1991], 180-82
"Desire and the Interpretation of Desire in Hamlet" [Excerpts from Seminar 6, 1958-59], ed. J.-A. Miller, trans. James Hulbert, Yale French Studies 55/56 [1977]: 11

Michael appears in the Chaucer Life-Records only as the recipient, as chancellor, of a privy-seal writ in 1383 ordering him to notify the collectors of the wool custom and subsidy that Chaucer would from that point be performing the controller's duties by deputy (165-66)

J. R. Hulbert, however, pointed out that Chaucer's appointment as justice of the peace in Kent in 1385 "must have been made by the Chancellor" (Chaucer's Official Life [Menasha, Wis.: Banta, 1912], 60)

Palmer's explanation of Pole's trip makes better sense than the chroniclers', which "was evidently circulated by the Appellants to ridicule de la Pole" (England, France, 110)
Pole finally could not obtain, owing to the French King's departure for Paris (111-12)

Pole returned to England, the Appellants put out the story that Beauchamp had returned him forcibly, "for they would not have wanted to drive William de Beauchamp into open opposition by accusing him of conspiring with traitors" (113)

Edward Vasta's denial that there is poetic justice in the Tale: the two students "beat the unconscious Miller without regard for honor, take all their goods without regard for justice, and escape with a claim not merely to equality but to superiority" ("How Chaucer's Reeve Succeeds," Criticism 25 [1983]: 9)
W. F. Woods's recent reference to "this added brutality" ("The Logic of Deprivation in the Reeve's Tale," Chaucer Review 30 [1995]: 158)

P. Olson, who says that the pilgrim Miller and the Reeve, the latter because of his preaching, stand for "the abuse of the powers of the two ruling estates" (Good Society, 45)

Georges Duby's is the classic history of this theory The Three Orders: Feudal Society Imagined [1978], trans. Arthur Goldhammer [Chicago: Univ. of Chicago Press, 1980])

H. S. Bennett, "The Reeve and the Manor in the Fourteenth Century," English Historical Review 41 [1926]: 362-63

Chaucer's Oswald had no honest path to prosperity, it is hard to see why his lord, when forced to borrow because he had lived beyond his own means, would give the Reeve a "thank" as well as a coat and hood, since any dishonest surplus must have come from him. No doubt, as Copland has suggested, the Reeve is something of a puritan before the letter (14-32)
Jill Mann, Chaucer and Medieval Estates Satire (Cambridge: Cambridge Univ. Press, 1973), 165
"The Reeve's Tale: Chaucer's Measure for Measure," Studies in Philology 59 [1962]: 5-16
Robert Burlin, Chaucerian Fiction [Princeton: Princeton Univ. Press, 1977], 157, 160
Ruggiers sees the sermon as redressing the "callous" neglect of old age in the Miller's Tale (68)
V. A. Kolve, Chaucer and the Imagery of Narrative: The First Five Canterbury Tales (Stanford: Stanford Univ. Press, 1984), 225

Laura Kendrick thinks the Reeve avenges an exposure of his "importance" first by conceding this disability, then going one up on the Miller by insisting on other deficits of old age (Chaucerian Play: Comedy and Control in the Canterbury Tales [Berkeley: Univ. of California Press, 1988], 123).
Kolve has suggested that moral scrutiny of the parson, the miller, and the miller's wife is "one way in which the 'sermonyng' of the prologue invades the tale" (235- 36)

Ruggiers remarks, "we may integrate this monologue of the Reeve on old age into his whole performance is, I suspect, a matter of enthusiasm and zeal for seeing all that Chaucer does as a finished performance" (69)
Adorno, 84.
Kolve, 229.

A. C. Spearing observes that "Claucer goes further than most of his contemporaries in the persistence with which he presents paternal authority as absent or cruel]" (Medieval to Renaissance in English Poetry [Cambridge: Cambridge Univ. Press, 1985], 95; compare 92-103)
